text: Speaking of random: Donald Knuth's introduction to the Random Number chapter of his classic "The Art of Computer Programming" should be required reading.  (Who am I kidding? The entire series probably should be!)

elements.text: Speaking of random: Donald Knuth's introduction to the Random Number chapter of his classic "The Art of Computer Programming" should be required reading.  (Who am I kidding? The entire series probably should be!)

text:
My parents got it as a gift when I got into university, because I kept going to the national library to sit in the reference section to read it.

But that chapter has quite interesting insights, but I remember it had fairly little in the way of generating numbers from a distribution.

elements.text:
My parents got it as a gift when I got into university, because I kept going to the national library to sit in the reference section to read it.

But that chapter has quite interesting insights, but I remember it had fairly little in the way of generating numbers from a distribution.

text: Yeah, it is kinda textbook expensive, but in terms of computer books it has had (and will continue to have IMHO) a very long shelf life.  In terms of monetary-unit-per-shelf-year it's not much worse than other books I've long since recycled. (But how many people buy physical books anymore?)
